name: Reishi Mushroom
summary: Reishi mushroom (Ganoderma lucidum) is a medicinal mushroom traditionally used for immune support, stress reduction, and longevity, with emerging evidence for neuroprotective and mental health benefits.
description: Reishi mushroom, known as Ganoderma lucidum or 'Lingzhi,' has been used in traditional Chinese and Japanese medicine for over 2,000 years. It contains bioactive compounds such as polysaccharides, triterpenes, and peptidoglycans, which are believed to modulate the immune system, reduce inflammation, and support stress resilience. Reishi is commonly used to promote relaxation, improve sleep quality, and support cardiovascular and metabolic health. In mental health contexts, it may influence fatigue, stress, and mood regulation, though evidence remains limited and primarily from preclinical and small clinical studies.

metadata.natural_source: Ganoderma lucidum fruiting body and spores
metadata.fda_status: Dietary supplement (not FDA-approved for medical indications)

items: May reduce fatigue and improve energy

sections.text: Reishi mushroom contains polysaccharides and triterpenes that modulate immune cell activity, reduce inflammation, and act as adaptogens. These compounds may influence stress response via the hypothalamic–pituitary–adrenal (HPA) axis and improve sleep by promoting parasympathetic nervous system activity. Neuroprotective effects are thought to stem from antioxidant and anti-inflammatory actions within the brain.

adult.typical: 1.5–5 g/day of dried mushroom or 500–1500 mg/day of extract (standardized to polysaccharides or triterpenes)
adult.note: Dosing varies significantly depending on extract concentration.

sections.pediatric: Not routinely recommended; limited safety data.

sections.text: Stress and sleep-related benefits may appear within 1–2 weeks; immune effects may require longer-term use (weeks to months).

other: May increase bleeding risk; use with caution if on blood thinners.
Not recommended for individuals with autoimmune disease without medical supervision.
Quality and potency vary widely among products.

items: Bleeding risk if combined with anticoagulants
Liver function with prolonged or high-dose use

sections.pregnancy: Not enough data; avoid unless supervised
sections.pediatrics: Not well studied; avoid supplementation outside clinical use
sections.geriatrics: Generally safe; monitor for interactions with medications

sections.text: No tapering required; may discontinue without withdrawal effects.

items: Considered an adaptogen in traditional medicine systems.
Often used in combination with other medicinal mushrooms (e.g., cordyceps, lion’s mane).
Evidence for psychiatric and sleep benefits remains preliminary.
